did.abstract: Richard B. Gregg (1885–1974) was an American social philosopher and pacifist influenced by Mahatma Gandhi's philosophy. The Richard B. Gregg Papers (dated 1936) contain a typed summary of Gregg's trip to England with reflections on meetings he had with various peoples as he promoted non-violence as a tactic of social change. The collection also contains a postcard written by Gregg to Mabel Bosworth promoting his book, The Power of Non-Violence. Photocopies of the typed trip summary, postcard, and The Power of Non-Violence book cover also exist in the collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Richard B. Gregg Papers (dated 1936) contain a typed summary of Gregg's trip to England with reflections on meetings he had with various peoples as he promoted non-violence as a tactic of social change. This was written in 1936 while Gregg was onboard the S.S. Bremen. The collection also contains a postcard written by Gregg to Mabel Bosworth promoting his book, The Power of Non-Violence. Photocopies of the typed trip summary, postcard, and The Power of Non-Violence book cover also exist in the collection.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Richard B. Gregg (1885–1974) was an American social philosopher and pacifist influenced by Mahatma Gandhi's philosophy. He formulated an early Western theory of nonviolent resistance, which informed the work of figures such as Martin Luther King Jr. and Bayard Rustin. He also connected his pacifist views to a broader idea of deliberate and simple living, which he called "voluntary simplicity." His book, The Power of Non-Violence (Philadelphia: J. B. Lippincott, 1934), introduced Gandhi's teachings to Western audiences. It was revised in 1944 (2nd edition) and again in 1959 (3rd edition), the latter including a foreword by Martin Luther King Jr.
